text: (director speaks indistinctly)
- Greetings. My name's Ryan.
I'm a partner solutions architect
with Amazon Web Services.

Joining me here today
is Fabio from Canonical.
Fabio, say hi.
- Hi. I'm Fabio.
I'm a senior staff support engineer

with the support engineering
team at Canonical.
- Well, welcome.
As always, talking about things
that are important to customers.

Fabio, many of my customers
are utilizing Ubuntu
in some fashion on AWS.
Some of them are using the LTS version.

Others are using the paid
sort of professional version
or Pro version of Ubuntu.
And a lot of questions we get are,
"When I hit a bump in the road,

when I as a customer am
struggling with something,

who's the best person
or who's the best entity
to reach out to for support?"
Now, obviously AWS does provide
a 24/7 support option.

We have it as a additional
paid-for service.

So, most of my customers will
go and buy a support offering
that's linked to their AWS accounts,
and for their non-production workloads,
that is potentially a developer support,
and for their production workloads,

depending on the size and
the nature of the business,
they might go for like a business support

or they might go for a
enterprise-level support.
But that support doesn't give them
all of the whistles and bells
for, say, an Ubuntu operating system.

I mean, the AWS team will help
them where it relates to AWS

or if it's something that
we're able to help out with,
you know, we'll try.

But, ultimately, if a customer
is running Ubuntu LTS,

that's a completely open-source
free operating system,
do they get support with that?
What's the support model for a customer
in that operating system?
- Correct.

So, typically when you
have a critical environment
running in your,
where you're running your workload,
you would expect to get

or you would look for
support from the experts,
from the creators of that product.

- You're talking like
a bank or an airline,
those sort of entities?
- Any kind of entity.
So, any Ubuntu users on the cloud,
if you would expect to get support,

nobody would be better
for giving you support
than the people that are preparing
the operating system for you

and the ones-
- Agreed.

- That are actually building
the distribution for you.
So, that would be Canonical.
So, for you to get support from Canonical,

the support offering is not
included in the LTS release

and it's actually also not
included in the Ubuntu Pro

that you may launch your
instances from in the AWS cloud.

So, there's a difference
between these two offerings,
and there's a additional item

that you can optionally contract
directly from Canonical,
which would be the support.
So, in the LTS release,

you would basically get
the packages from Universe
and from the main repositories.
And with Ubuntu Pro,
there's additional security fixes
that we provide through repositories

that Ubuntu Pro entitled
instances would get access to.
- Now, you're talking support
in the context of break-fix maintenance

of the applications, the
components of the operating system,
sort of patch management,

that kind of support.
- Right.

- What if I had an issue
where I was struggling
to configure an application
and I wanted to talk
to like a call center type support agent?

Is that possible with LTS
or the non-Pro version
or am I going to like a community support
forum type environment?

- It's possible, and this
is where you would look

for contracting support
from Canonical directly.
So, what you are describing

is basically looking
for ticketing support,
like getting phone support
or being able to get to a support portal
and opening a ticket,
describing your problem, your question,

the issue you're facing or what
you're trying to accomplish

and how to get, and getting
help from experts to it.

So, this is basically where
you would contact Canonical

so that you can buy support
from us, get support from us,
and then you would be entitled
to opening support cases with us

and get help from experts
that would be able

to address (indistinct).
- So, very similar to AWS.

A customer would purchase
a support package
and they would get support
for their workloads running Canonical
and they can reach out directly.
That's not sold through AWS.
I'm assuming a customer need to reach out
to somebody in Canonical

and purchase that
support package directly.
- That's correct.

Then you would be encouraged
to go into our website
and contacting your support representative
and then you can contract,
you can get support from us directly.
You would receive credentials
for accessing our support portal
and instructions for you to be able
to open a support ticket with us.

And then you would have
access to a team of experts
that are available 24,

depending on how you would
like to have that contract,
it could be 24 by 5 or 24 by 7,
that would include weekend support,

over several different
countries, geographies,
that have experts available

to help you circumvent the
issue that you're dealing with.

- So, you don't necessarily
have different support tiers.

It's really, do I require
support for my business
on a Monday to Friday,
or do I have a requirement
for a full seven-day, 24/7 support cycle?
I imagine the vast majority of customers
are just going 7 by 24.
- It makes sense,

especially if you have
critical environment
that if something happens on the weekend,
you need immediate support from somebody
to assist you with that,
then you would require 24 by 7 support.
- The 5 by 24,

is that more sort of a
non-prod development workload

sort of happening Monday
to Friday type thing?
- Exactly.

Anything that doesn't
require continuous support
over the weekend.

So, maybe a development,
a staging environment,
that if something breaks over the week,

nobody will die if you just
wait until Monday morning
to resume work on this.
So, then you can pause on Friday
and then resume working on it on Monday.

But otherwise it would
be recommended for you
to get the 24 by 7

because we provide a
follow-the-sun model of support.
So, that would be continuous.

So, basically, if you
have something critical
that needs immediate attention,

as long as you can
continue to work with us
to support your environment,
then we can go over through the weekend

and work on this until
we can figure it out.

- Now, AWS and Canonical
have been partners
for a very long time.

The operating system's been
running on AWS for many years.
From an engineering standpoint,
we've got a close relationship.

So, as AWS encounters
areas of improvement,

whether that is through
our EC2 service team
or whether we get voice of the customer
around something that needs to change,
AWS does have that partner relationship

and we do work with
Canonical's engineering teams

to, you know, bring that voice
of the customer to Canonical,
Canonical address that,
and that typically comes back down
through the patch management
to the main distribution channels

that you have within the
operating system itself.
Is there any element
that we have maybe forgotten to talk about
or things that you feel we should mention

that is important to customers
with regards to support?
- Right, yeah, so, Canonical and AWS
have a longstanding relationship
and there's a contract in place

where Canonical works
closely with AWS engineers

to make sure that Ubuntu
runs smoothly on AWS cloud.
There are engagements related to support
where issues, questions, requests,

optimizations that would
come from AWS through us
would be related to the partnership,
the platform engagement.
So, it could be anything related
to how Ubuntu is generally running on AWS
that could potentially affect
any Ubuntu instance running on the cloud.
That includes, for example,
image optimization, kernel optimization.
So, for example, you may realize
that there's a linux-aws kernel
that runs in your Ubuntu instances

that means that it's a
kernel that is customized

and prepared by kernel
engineers at Canonical

to include all the changes
that would be required

for that to run smoothly on
AWS cloud on your hardware.

That does not mean that it
includes support engagement
for workload specific.

So, if it's something specific
to a customer use case,
something, for example,

on how they are deploying
their application
or how they're using it
and they would like to have direct access
to Canonical experts,

then this is when they
should contact us directly
to get support from us.
- Okay.

Fabio, as always, it's a
pleasure having you here.
Thank you for joining us.
- Thank you.
It's a pleasure to be here as well.
- And thank you for joining us.
